tests.title: Epistemological Limits
tests.text: (1) has long been recognised that human knowledge is subject to inherent limitations. (2) the extent to which we can ever attain objective truth remains contested. Some philosophers have argued (3) all observation is theory-laden; (4) maintain that certain propositions are beyond doubt. The distinction (5) knowledge and belief is (6) no means straightforward. (7) the former is often taken to require justification, the criteria (8) such justification are themselves debated.

tests.title: Constitutional Interpretation
tests.text: The question of (1) the constitution ought to be interpreted has divided scholars for generations. Originalists insist (2) the document must be read in light of the framers' intent; (3) take the view that it is a living instrument. (4) the one hand, the former approach claims the virtue of constraining judicial discretion. (5) the other, the latter allows for adaptation to changing circumstances. (6) is at stake is not merely legal technicality (7) the very nature of democratic legitimacy. The debate (8) unlikely to be resolved soon.

tests.title: Literary Canon Formation
tests.text: (1) constitutes the canon of great literature is a question (2) has provoked considerable controversy. Those (3) defend the traditional list do (4) on the grounds that it embodies enduring value. Critics, (5) the other hand, point to the exclusion of marginalised voices. The process (6) which works achieve canonical status is (7) means transparent. (8) is clear is that canons evolve over time.

tests.title: Scientific Paradigms
tests.text: Kuhn's notion of paradigm shifts has been influential (1) not without its detractors. (2) is disputed is whether science progresses through revolutions (3) through accumulation. (4) the former view, periods of normal science are punctuated (5) crises that give rise to new frameworks. (6) the latter, change is more gradual. (7) is undeniable is that the concept has shaped (8) we think about the history of science.

tests.title: Moral Particularism
tests.text: Moral particularists reject the idea (1) sound reasoning requires appeal to general principles. (2) their view, the morally salient features of a situation cannot be captured (3) a set of rules. (4) has led some to charge them with leaving too much (5) judgment. Defenders reply (6) principles either collapse into truisms (7) prove too rigid. The debate touches (8) the nature of practical reason itself.

tests.title: Linguistic Relativity
tests.text: The hypothesis (1) language shapes thought has been both influential and contested. (2) strongest form, it holds that speakers of different languages inhabit distinct conceptual worlds. (3) its weakest, it suggests only that language can influence certain cognitive tasks. Evidence (4) the former has been elusive; (5) the latter is better supported. (6) is clear is that the relationship (7) language and thought is (8) of simple characterisation.

tests.title: Historical Causation
tests.text: Historians have long debated (1) extent individual agency determines the course of events. (2) one view, great figures are the prime movers; (3) another, structural forces render their role negligible. Most scholars would now accept (4) the truth lies somewhere (5) between. (6) is at issue is not (7) individuals matter (8) how their scope for action is constrained.

tests.title: Aesthetic Judgment
tests.text: (1) Kant argued, aesthetic judgment is disinterested yet (2) claims universal validity. (3) has proved difficult to reconcile these two features. Some have sought to ground the latter (4) our shared cognitive capacities; (5) have looked to social practice. The status of so-called judgments of taste remains (6) the heart of the discussion. (7) is agreed is that the phenomenon resists straightforward analysis. (8) the least, it demands careful attention to the use of key terms.

tests.title: Political Obligation
tests.text: (1) grounds, if any, do citizens have an obligation to obey the law? Consent theorists answer (2) we are bound because we have agreed to be so. (3) object that few have given anything (4) could plausibly count as consent. Alternative accounts appeal (5) fairness, necessity or gratitude. (6) account has commanded universal assent. The problem is (7) deep that some have concluded (8) there is no general obligation.

tests.title: Consciousness and Explanation
tests.text: The place of consciousness in the natural world remains deeply puzzling. Physicalists hold (1) mental states are nothing over (2) above physical states. (3) is less clear is how to accommodate the subjective character of experience. Some have suggested (4) the problem is illusory; (5) maintain that we need a radical reconception of the physical. (6) the meantime, research in neuroscience continues to illuminate the neural (7) of various conscious states. (8) whether this will resolve the philosophical issue is another matter.
